bestBHT.bht: Blessed are those who weep audibly now, for they shall laugh with a charming liveliness, expressing the comfort that awaits them in the future. This hunger and weeping will eventually be filled, and they will be satisfied with spiritual joy and pleasure, finding consolation and comfort in the blessings that lie ahead.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: liveliness of this word, to express what in Matthew is called being
Marvin Vincent: Shall be filled. See on Matthew 5:6.
Weep [κλαιοντες] . Strictly, to weep audibly. See on qountev, mourn, Matthew 5:4.
Archibald T. Robertson: This sharpens the contrast between present sufferings and the future blessings.
Luke here omits 'and thirst after righteousness.'
John Gill: Blessed are ye that hunger now... for ye shall be filled."
Blessed are ye that weep now... for ye shall laugh."
Be filled with spiritual joy and pleasure, and be comforted with the consolations of the Spirit.

bhtAttempts.bht: Blessed are those who weep audibly now, for they shall laugh with a charming liveliness, expressing the comfort that awaits them in the future. Luke's sharp words emphasize the contrast between present sufferings and future blessings, as he omits the part about thirsting after righteousness. This hunger and weeping will eventually be filled, and they will be filled with spiritual joy and pleasure, finding comfort in the consolations of the Spirit.

Blessed are those who weep audibly now, for they shall laugh with a charming liveliness, expressing the comfort that awaits them in the future. This hunger and weeping will eventually be filled, and they will be filled with spiritual joy and pleasure, finding comfort in the consolations of the Spirit.

This hunger and weeping will eventually be filled, and they will be filled with spiritual joy and pleasure as they are comforted by the consolations of the Spirit.

This hunger and weeping will eventually be filled, and they will be satisfied with spiritual joy and pleasure, finding consolation and comfort in the blessings that lie ahead.

This hunger and weeping will eventually be filled, and they will be filled with spiritual joy and pleasure, finding comfort in the consolations of the Spirit.
